dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, I was reading this article, and it really dug into, um, Kolanovic's report about the next financial crisis. Kind of a heavy topic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, I was reading this article, and it really dug into, um, Kolanovic's report about the next financial crisis. Kind of a heavy topic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, the "Great Liquidity Crisis" report. Pretty intense stuff. What stuck out to you most?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, the Great Liquidity Crisis report. Pretty intense stuff. What stuck out to you most?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Kolanovic explains as part of a 168 report issued earlier this month, a precipitous decline in stocks could cause the Great Liquidity Crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the idea that a big stock decline, like, combined with lightning-fast machine selling and even central bank action, could just snowball.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the idea that a big stock decline, like, combined with lightning-fast machine selling and even central bank action, could just snowball.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Severe stock price declines. Lightening fast machine selling. Aggressive action by central banks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And he really points to passive investing and algorithmic trading as, like, the big backdrops for this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And he really points to passive investing and algorithmic trading as, like, the big backdrops for this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The rise of passive investing and algorithmic trading could create the backdrop for a substantial stock market drop, according to Kolanovic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. Because all that money shifting to passive, you lose those individual buyers who traditionally step in when prices fall, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. Because all that money shifting to passive, you lose those individual buyers who traditionally step in when prices fall, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The approximately $2 trillion shift from active to passive investing has removed individual buyers who can buy the market after significant price declines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And, um, 90% of daily trading is from index and quant funds. They're just programmed to sell weakness, not analyze anything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And, um, ninety percent of daily trading is from index and quant funds. They're just programmed to sell weakness, not analyze anything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Kolanovic, 90% of daily trading in the stock market is from index and quant funds. Quant funds, he writes, are programmed to sell market weakness - rather than analyze fundamental valuation, for example.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, flash crashes during a recession... that's kind of untested territory, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, flash crashes during a recession... that's kind of untested territory, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While more recent flash crashes have occurred during periods of economic expansion, flash crashes during a recessionary period are less tested.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Could lead to even bigger asset value declines, more volatility. It's a scary thought.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Could lead to even bigger asset value declines, more volatility. It's a scary thought.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic predicts those flash crashes could lead to declines in asset values and increased market volatility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He didn't put a hard date on it, though, did he? Like, when this might happen?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He didn't put a hard date on it, though, did he? Like, when this might happen?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not really, but he did mention potential problems not until the second half of 2019, [interrupts] but factors like a trade war or interest rate hikes could speed things up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not really, but he did mention potential problems not until the second half of twenty nineteen, but factors like a trade war or interest rate hikes could speed things up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an interview with CNBC, Kolanovic said that while it's not possible to predict the timing of the next financial crisis, he doesn't see potential problems until the second half of 2019. A trade war with China, the speed of interest rate hikes and the unwinding of bond purchases by the Federal Reserve are factors that could change that timeline.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And if it gets really bad, like a 40% market drop, the Fed might have to, uh, buy equities or even cut taxes?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And if it gets really bad, like a forty percent market drop, the Fed might have to, uh, buy equities or even cut taxes?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic notes that if markets fall by 40% or more, for example, the Federal Reserve may need to take drastic action to prevent a depression. This would mean the Federal Reserve could purchase equities or attempt to stimulate the economy through additional tax cuts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, pretty drastic stuff to prevent a depression. But also, you know, we can't forget about consumer debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, pretty drastic stuff to prevent a depression. But also, you know, we can't forget about consumer debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, good point. All that mortgage, credit card, student loan debt... it's a lot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, good point. All that mortgage, credit card, student loan debt... it's a lot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. consumers collectively hold more than $1 trillion in each of mortgage debt, student loan debt and credit card debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Especially student loans. Over a trillion and a half dollars. It's now the second-highest consumer debt category.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially student loans. Over a trillion and a half dollars. It's now the second-highest consumer debt category.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the latest student loan debt statistics from Make Lemonade, there are over 44 million borrowers who collectively owe $1.5 trillion in student loan debt. This now makes student loan debt the second highest consumer debt category - second only to mortgages.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, if this "Great Liquidity Crisis" actually happens, what can people *do*?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, if this Great Liquidity Crisis actually happens, what can people do?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Kolanovic suggests a few things. You could just do nothing. Analysts have been predicting a crash for ages, and it hasn't happened.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Kolanovic suggests a few things. You could just do nothing. Analysts have been predicting a crash for ages, and it hasn't happened.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So, what are your options if a stock market sell-off ensues and there is a Great Liquidity Crisis? While there are multiple options that you could consider, here are three potential strategies: 1. Do Nothing... Zack Friedman, Forbes Senior Contributor

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Or, like, sell some chips off the table. Protect yourself, but then you miss the upside if it keeps going up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, like, sell some chips off the table. Protect yourself, but then you miss the upside if it keeps going up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 2. Sell It's common sense: if you fear that the market will crash, you can take some chips off the table. ... Of course, if the market continues to rise, you miss out on the upside.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And then there's hedging, like buying put options on the S&P 500. You make money if it drops, but lose the premium if it doesn't.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And then there's hedging, like buying put options on the S and P five hundred. You make money if it drops, but lose the premium if it doesn't.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 3. Hedge There are many ways to hedge your investments. One option is to buy S&P 500 put options to protect against a market decline. When you buy covered put options, you make money if the market drops. If the market doesn't drop, you lose the premium you paid for the put option.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, some options to consider, but no easy answers for sure. A lot to keep an eye on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, some options to consider, but no easy answers for sure. A lot to keep an eye on.
